newsitem.title: SOUTH AFRICA: Alusaf critical of EU aluminium tariffs.
newsitem.headline: Alusaf critical of EU aluminium tariffs.

text.p: South African aluminium producer Alusaf, a unit of Gencor Ltd, on Wednesday said it would regard Europe as a natural market if European Union tariffs on primary aluminium were removed.
"If the duty was removed, then we would look to Europe as a natural market," Alusaf managing director Rob Barbour told Reuters.
Alusaf, one of the world's largest producers of aluminium, was currently selling most of its metal outside the EU because of the tariffs -- currently six percent for primary aluminium ingot.
"It doesn't impact on us immediately. Because of that duty we in fact export most of our metal to other parts of the world where there is no duty," Barbour said in an interview.
"We just find it rather peculiar that a developing country should have all its import protection on primary (aluminium) removed and its protection on semi- and manufactured goods severely cut back.
"At the same time we cannot export our primary metal into Europe. It seems a bit of an anomaly," he added.
Alusaf is one of the most succesful greenfields aluminium producers in the world, with production at its Hillside smelter currently exceeding design capacity.
Barbour said current production at Hillside was running at around 495,000 tonnes a year while the design capacity was 466,000 tonnes.
Alusaf said in August -- when the Hillside smelter was running at a capacity of 490,000 tonnes -- it expected aluminium production to be around 665,000 tonnes in the year to end-June 1997.
